turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: What are we standing on?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Faith.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Bring the motor around.  Bang out in front, right?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You goin' back inside?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: One thing I need.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Steady on.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You steady on, man.  What the fuck else did you do back there.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Why didn't you just kill him, you had the chance.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: That would be too easy.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Too easy?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: He's gotta know why.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You think a fuckin' guy like that ever will?  What more do you want, man?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I've been wondering something.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Again?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Do you have any friends, man?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah, I suppose.  Call 'em that, yeah. Down the boozer Saturday night.  Meet some of the lads.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Useless gits.  I was gonna do the Post Office once.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What post office?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: The lot.  The whole British bloody Post Office.  I had a brilliant plan -- all worked out -- work of genius, it was. Could I get anybody interested?  No -- they're too busy pinching orange squash from the milkman.  Lazy sods.  Jumble sale on in Watford, they'll be up at the crack of dawn.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: What d'you say, Elaine?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Not much -- you?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Same.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Last time I saw you, weren't you up for some equity-waiver thing?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Probably.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I was gonna be in that Michael Mann movie, you know -- with Pacino and DeNiro.  Got three callbacks.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Didn't get it.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Well, those are the breaks.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Not no more, they ain't.  I quit that acting shit, man.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You just cooking then?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hell, no.  I started writing.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hey, Elaine.  You even know what he's saying half the time?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No, but I know what he means.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ... Reminds me of Jennifer.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Hard to miss.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I thought maybe you just came for the ride.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I'd rather be with him than without him. I don't want to be found dead in L.A.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Had a feeling it was you.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You look alike.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Perhaps it was the smoke.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Not her brand.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: She used to pinch 'em off me.  Funny that.  One thing she never tried to get me to stop.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Why did you come here?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Wanted to talk to you, didn't I?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No, why did you come here?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Sort a few things out.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Been busy, have you.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: How d'you mean?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It's been a while.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I was skint -- didn't have no money to get here.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: That's not what I heard.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: What was that, then?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I heard you were -- what's that adorable phrase? -- "at Her Majesty's pleasure."

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: It was the bars, then.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: In any case, I don't suppose the salary you make sewing mailbags is really commensurate with international airline travel.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Sewing mailbags?  Me?  Never did an honest day's work in my life, dear. Wasn't about to start when I was in stir -- not with all that leisure time on my hands.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: And not with all that buried loot you had waiting for you when you got out.  From the Wembley Staduim job, wasn't it?  Pink Floyd concert receipts.  Jenny would've been ... fourteen at the time?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Hardly buried.  Earning interest, love. Earning interest in an offshore account. Tidy little premium per annum, that.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Well, that kind of security can't be bought.  Must be more comforting than a daughter to greet you.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Here, aren't you gonna let me in.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Try calling me again.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: ... No, I went in for more improving pastimes.  Philosophy classes, language courses, European history, all that lark. Did you know that in Paris in the Eighteenth Century there were more rats in people's houses than there were people in people's houses.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Sounds like Beverly Hills.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Here, are you always this sarky?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Sarcastic, moi?  Maybe I'll mellow when my ship comes in.  It's expected any day now.  I'm all packed and ready to go.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Weren't you on a television series?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: If it played in England somebody owes me money.  Who told you that -- Eddie?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Said it went on for donkey's years.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Three seasons.  They found that's the limit of human tolerance when it comes to following the adventures of a family of Mormons on the Chisum Trail.  I was wife number three -- the ingenue.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Oh, it just ended, then.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Now who's being sarcastic?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: When you've lost as many years as I have, love, puts things in perspective, know what I mean.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I guess the rest of us have no excuse for wondering where the time went.  It must've been the bars.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I can't believe Jenny told you all that. About me.  She was always so embarrassed.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Not embarrassed.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Ashamed.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Not ashamed.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Disappointed.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: She never told Eddie, though.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: She never told anyone else.  About the convict strain -- or is it stain?  No, I was privileged.  I was someone who helped Jenny efface her past.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: How'd you manage that, then.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: When I'm not honing my craft in episodic television I do double-duty as a voice coach.  Not that her accent would have hobbled her progress.  Not with that look.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah, well, she started all that in London.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Modelling.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Learnin' 'ow to speak proper.  Central School of Speech and Drama. It's no doddle gettin' in there, y'know. At seventeen.  They offered her a place at RADA n' all, only she'd've had to wait till the next session and she was always in hurry to get on, was Jenny.  She could talk posh without any training, when she was knee-high to a grasshopper.  Show up the old man, you know.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You weren't disappointed in her, then.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: In Jenny?  'Course not.  How could I be. 'Course I wasn't.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: She was twenty-one when she came to me.  ... Straight from leaving you.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Footloose and fancy free.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: She was happy here.  However the two of you might have parted.  Don't think she wasn't.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: When did you get in?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yesterday.  Afternoon.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You haven't been lurking outside my building all day.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: No, I had -- some other matters to attend to, you know.  Getting a car sorted ...

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I might've been away for the weekend.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Well, I reckoned, Saturday night, if you were goin' out, you'd probably have to come home first.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: And you've seen Eddie Rama.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah, saw Eddie, yeah.  Me and him are muckers.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I should really give him a call.  He's a character, isn't he.  Well, not to you. I meant to us squares in the outside world.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: He give me your address.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I gave him yours.  Said, here, you want to write, I think this is a relative.  I guess I thought I was being true to Jenny.  Who told me she didn't have a father -- before proceeding of course to tell me why.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Well, don't suppose she did, really, most of her life.  On her own after her mum died.  Aunts and uncles for a time -- and then the bright lights beckoned.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Were you still married at the time -- to Jenny's mother, I mean?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Nah, we split up when Jenny was six.  Her second husband done a runner after she got sick.  They give me compassionate leave from Parkhurst to go visit her in hospital.  We were always mates, me and Jenny's mum.  I like to think they're together again now.  Y'know.  Heavenly choir.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: The address Jenny gave me, that wasn't a prison, was it?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Nah, accommodation address.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What's that, like a P.O. box.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Something like that, yeah.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Where you get your bank statements.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I already knew.  Knew beforehand.  When was it supposed to have happened? -- two o'clock in the morning, Eddie said.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: That's what was estimated.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Eight hours difference between here and London.  Would've been, what, ten in the morning, my time.  I was just coming out on the yard.  Now, I was in the habit of saving my newspaper till then.  Bit of fresh air, stretch me legs -- well, stretch the day out, really, that's what you wanna do.  And I'll tell ya:  I couldn't open the paper.  Could not pry the pages apart -- it was like they was glued together.  That's how weak my hands went.  Thought I was having heart attack, only I knew I wasn't.  Bloke come up to me, he says, Dave, he says, you've gone all white.  I said, fuck me, I've been in prison half my life, what d'ya expect. But he was dead on, 'cause I could feel the blood drain right out of me head. And I knew ...  Something had happened to Jen.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Do you even know who Terry Valentine is?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Well, I gathered something from the article what Eddie sent me.  Some sort of pop music producer, wasn't it.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Lives high off the hog and waits for the next big thing.  Like me -- but on a grander scale of failure.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Now, you shouldn't run yourself down.  My employer, Mr. Lindgren --

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: -- Your employer?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: -- Mr. Lindgren.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Who's Mr. Lindgren?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: My employer.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What line is he in.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Proprietor of a London firm.  Of longstanding.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Based in London, but with international concerns.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I bet.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Various enterprises, style of thing.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I thought you said you never did an honest day's work in your life.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Well, not to say Mr. Lindgren is dishonest, exactly.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Anyhow, he's always saying to me, Dave, never run yourself down, son -- 'cause there'll always be plenty of people willing to do it for you.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: In what capacity are you employed by this Mr. Lindgren?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: This and that.  Y'know.  Ways and means.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: -- When he wants someone run down, you're willing to do it for him.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: So what's the deal.  You and Terry Valentine at twenty paces.  Is that what this is about.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Why not.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Are you serious.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Have you ever known me not to be.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You fuckin' guys and your dicks.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: What'd you want me to do.  Stay at home, twiddlin' me thumbs.  Doing sweet F.A. [Fuck All].

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You don't believe it was a car accident.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: What do you think.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Terry's never going to give you satisfaction.  Not the type.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Depends, don' it.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: On what.  What makes you so certain.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I'll bloody well ask him.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: There's the phone.  You want his number.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Jenny was supposed to come to my place that night.  She called me, asked if she could come over.  She and Terry had been -- having some trouble.  Lately.  I don't know about what.  On this occasion, it reached some sort of crisis point.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: She told you all about my details but not about his.  Lovely.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: She'd never called me like that before. She sounded more ... pissed off -- angry -- than upset or afraid.  But she never turned up.  I called the house but only got the answer machine.  When they found her ... she'd been going the wrong way. Not the direction she'd have gone if she'd been coming to see me.  Or coming <u>straight</u> to see me.  Who knows.  Maybe she just wanted to drive.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: How did you come to have my address? Found it, did you.  Among her things.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You think Terry gave me access to her things?  Probably sold her clothes.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: And how did you get it?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: This town's been chewing my flesh since ... what we now refer to as "the early 70's."  Christ, my past became nostalgia and no one even asked me.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Early 70's.  I was away.  Maidstone.  Possibly Brixton.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: These more highlights from the Zagat prison guide?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: You don't seem bothered.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You don't know how I've compromised my standards.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Tell us about it.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It's too involved; a lifetime of non- involvement.  Anywhere else I'd be an interesting little number, here I'm just SAG number forty-eight thousand and one.  SAG meaning Screen Actor's Guild.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Oh, I was gonna say ...

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Still, there have been rewards.  It's sunny.  And some of the producers who call even have credits.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I can see the attraction.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What did you do?  To make them take the early 70's away from you.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: A jeweller's up the West End.  We tunnelled our way under the shop floor from the public lavatory down the road. Filthy work.  Trouble was, the bloody thing collapsed -- <u>after</u> we'd made the grab, 'n all.  Would you Adam n' Eve it.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You mean if they'd nabbed you before you actually broke and entered you would only have been charged with making a mess.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: We were <u>lucky</u> to be nicked.  Me and the lads went down there Sunday evening, we weren't discovered till the Monday.  Good job we were still breathing.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It didn't discourage you, though.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Hey?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: From pursuing your chosen profession.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I'll tell ya something:  it made me a model prisoner.  Put me right off any escape attempts.  Tunnel my way to freedom after that experience?  Not bloody likely.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I was inside once.  I punched a cop at a demo.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Did you.  What was that in aid of?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Who remembers.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Get seven years, did you?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Overnight.  What about just now?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Just now?  Overnight?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You <u>have</u> been away.  Or is all this just new to you?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: It's true.  Has to be said.  I got off to a slow start.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Honest.  Didn't know where to look till I was 21.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Pushing the legal limit even then.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: -- they want Southern, I do Southern, they want Midwest, I do Midwest, they want tall, blonde, and twenty-two, I'm shit out of luck.  One thing I can't do is English. Americans can't.  Shouldn't even try. And Laurence Olivier couldn't do us.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: You ever been to London?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Only in the movies.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I've 'ardly ever left it.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Yeah, well, you're here now --  -- where <u>h</u>urricanes <u>h</u>ardly ever <u>h</u>appen.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I've got the hang of the driving.  Found this place all right.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Stick with me, kid.  Looks big when you get here but you can cover it in five minutes.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Not that I recall.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What about your grandmother?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Nah -- she was married to me grandad -- he was as bent as a boomerang -- used to make knuckle-dusters down the shop. Crafty old sod.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: He alive to see this?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Dropped dead in the stalls in the Odeon, Muswell Hill.  Watching Doris Day.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What'd your father do?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Black market during the war.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I guess you're just habitual.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: You sound like my fucking probation officer.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Won't he be looking for you about now?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Good luck to him.  He couldn't find his prick if he didn't wear Y-fronts.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Minor officials bother you, don't they?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Do us a favor.  Can't even go have a slash without 'em saying, what're you going in there for?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I got a steady income -- I'm on the dole.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: A leech on the welfare state in addition. You don't miss a trick.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I fiddle it.  They got me down as an immigrant with five kids.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Last time might as well've been the first.  I remember all the times, don't I.  Watching her grow up --  in increments.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: She told me you were a ghost in her life. Daddy the friendly ghost.  Coming back to haunt her.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Well, she twigged by the time she was eight or nine that daddy wasn't in the Royal Marines or doing scientific research in the jungles of Borneo or playing Iago in a worldwide tour of OTHELLO.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Still, you could never ... do what she wanted.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: She used to tell me she'd turn me in.  Little kid.  Ten year old.  "If you're naughty, Dad, I'll tell on ya."  She didn't want me sent down again, see. When I was planning some job.  "I'll tell 'em, Dad, I promise I will.  Here, look, I'm calling the Old Bill right now" -- picking up the telephone.  I can see her, the phone in her hand.  Became a sort of joke between us.  Only it wasn't a joke.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: She never would have turned you in, not in a million years.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I know that.  But as time went on ... well, it <u>wasn't</u> a joke, was it?  She had a feeling about it -- about the last job -- how long I'd get the hook for.  Said she wouldn't be there this time when I got out.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Where's Big Sur?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Up the coast.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: How far?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I don't know -- few hours, I guess.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Fancy it?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I could use a vacation.  Of course, I keep forgetting, for you this <u>is</u> a vacation.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Never thought of that.  Busman's holiday.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What's in Big Sur?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: That's where Valentine's scarpered.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Bloke told me.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Friends and <u>colleagues</u>.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: You can't count on very many people, that's the trouble.  Number of times a decent job's been cocked up ...

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Poor baby.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You're just on a higher plane, Wilson.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Too bleeding true, 'n' it.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: There's one thing I don't understand.  The thing I don't understand ... is every motherfucking thing you're saying.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Look, mush, you're the guv'nor here, I can see that, I'm on your manor now, right.  So there's no need to get out of your pram.  I'm Johnny-come-lately to all this.  Whatever the bollocks between you and this slag Valentine, it's got nothing to do with me.  I don't wanna know.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: Well, I'll tell you.  I believe this Valentine screwed me out of a fair sum of money.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I can well believe it.  I'm sure he has done, son.  He's about as straight as a dog's hind leg.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: But I can't be sure.  I don't even know who he is.  He's too insulated.  Too many layers around him.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Your guess is as good as mine, mate.  I'm here on another matter entirely.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: Yeah, I guess you are.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Good job your lot showed up when they did or it would've been <u>me</u> for the high jump.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: That dude who works for Valentine.  He's the one sent those guys after you.  You know that.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah.  Shouldn't wonder.  Must've done.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: So what's your beef, pal?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Nothing financial.  Strictly personal.  I can see how all this import-export malarkey might give rise to confusion where I'm concerned.  A foreigner, showing up unexpectedly, like.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: It was you.  Downtown.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Eh?

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: Because that wasn't anything to do with me.  And suspicion has been cast in my direction.  Didn't make any sense.  Choosing those shitheads over me, cutting me out of the deal, then screwing them over too.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: No, I can reassure you on that point. Valentine was just as surprised by that turn of events as you.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: He'd already grabbed more than his allotted cut.  Didn't think he'd be so bold as to take all of it.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: All of what?

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: Of the deal, man.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Oh, yeah, right.  The deal.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: But if you're mad at him too and he's mad at you ... that must make us pals.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: As you prefer, squire.  As you prefer.

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: In which case I'll just do what I usually do.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: And that is?

turns.speaker: FEATHER
turns.text: What am I doing?

turns.speaker: GRAMMS
turns.text: Valentine had himself a party, I hear.

turns.speaker: FIELDING
turns.text: My client has already given a statement regarding yesterday's events.

turns.speaker: GRAMMS
turns.text: A <u>statement</u>?  I wouldn't mind getting a statement.  You see, <u>my</u> client -- the United States Government -- would love to get a statement about a few of the deals going down with your client.

turns.speaker: FIELDING
turns.text: Deals?  My client is involved in any number of deals at any given moment. You'd have to be more specific.

turns.speaker: GRAMMS
turns.text: Your client have a deal in Long Beach? How about downtown?  There's some folks there -- oh, wait, they're all dead.  Any of this ring a bell?

turns.speaker: FIELDING
turns.text: My client is an entrepreneur.  I am his lawyer, not his business manager.

turns.speaker: GRAMMS
turns.text: So you wouldn't have any idea how your client continues to make so much fucking money.

turns.speaker: FIELDING
turns.text: He's always been very forward-thinking. He invested wisely.

turns.speaker: GRAMMS
turns.text: Where is he now?

turns.speaker: FIELDING
turns.text: He had urgent business in the north.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Don't you work with Ian?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Ian?

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: I could swear I met you with Ian at the EMI offices in London.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Sorry.  Wasn't me.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Unless I'm not who I think I am.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: That's too bad.  Ian's got a good thing going over there.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Turned that place completely around.  180 degrees.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: No kidding.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: What I like about Ian, he believes in a chain of command, but not a chain of respect, you understand what I'm saying?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Right.  Chain of respect.  That's good, that.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Yeah.  I really admire the guy.  Well. Good to meet you.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah.  Cheers, mate.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah, that's right.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: I can never decide what I like better. Leaving home, or coming back.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I would have preferred staying home, me.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: You're a reluctant traveller, then.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: You'll be looking forward to getting back, then.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah.  Another little matter needs attending to soon as I return.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: No rest for the wicked.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Been away a lot.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: Where else?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Out on a oil rig.  In the North Sea. Nine years.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: Nine years?  Is that legal?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Well, time off for good behavior, you know.  I shouldn't have even been there -- it was these other blokes who shoulda gone in my place.  I got lumbered with the job they were responsible for.  I don't mind pulling me own cart, but not someone else's, know what I mean.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: But you stuck it out, anyway, all that time.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I had to, didn't I.  Nothing else for it. Then just when I'd finished my nine years -- my contract -- wallop, I had to bugger off to the States.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: Sounds like you need a rest.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Could do, yeah.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: But first I gotta give these lads a talking to, these geezers what sent me up the river, in a manner of speaking.

turns.speaker: LADY
turns.text: The ones whose burden you took upon your own shoulders.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: How much.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Five thousand.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I got half.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: Makin' trouble for someone?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: Which kind?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: The forever kind.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Ever take a look at the women who work in pet stores?  Wow.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Good luck.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Jesus, are you gay enough or what.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Very attractive.  Good idea.  Now I <u>really</u> want to fuck you.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: ... you can always tell the ones who'll do anal.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Kinda makes you wonder why more people don't put a bullet through their fuckin' skulls, doesn't it.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Looks like they just airbrushed the dick out of his mouth.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Why don't they have TV shows about people whose daily lives you'd be interested in watching.  Y'know.  Like SKINNY LITTLE WEAKLING.  Or BIG FAT GUY.  SICK OLD MAN. FAMILY OF LOSERS.  Wouldn't that be good?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Two blacks and a Mexican in a car.  Who's driving?

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: The L.A.P.D.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: Maybe she doesn't even know the English guy.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Avery said she was tight with his daughter.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: That don't mean nothin'.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: She's nice lookin'.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: So what.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: I dunno.  I just said she's nice lookin'.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: And I said so what.  You think she's any happier?

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: What d'you mean, any happier?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Any happier than any other asshole in life.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Straight rotation, no shit, call your shot.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: Lemme break.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: We coulda used the other two-and-a-half grand.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: There's more than a measly few grand in this.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: There is?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Something's on.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I happen to know more about Mr. Whatever- his-name-is than he thinks I know about him and his operation.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You bet.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: Like what.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Like he'd never hire me for real.  Not week-to-week.  I don't have the credentials.  He thinks I'm just a sociopath, someone he can turn to when he needs "plausible denial."

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: Well, we blew it, didn't we?  He ain't wrong.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: "He ain't wrong."  Listen, I know this asshole who <u>did</u> just go to work for him. Full-time.  And this dickhead's parents just told me he took a road trip up the coast.  <u>That's</u> the type of individual gets hired, someone who'll shoot his mouth off to his family while on the job.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: I don't get it.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: I don't know who that English guy is. Some kind of --  -- courier or something.  Maybe a seller. Maybe a buyer.  But Mr. <u>Avery</u> wanted him, those jigs wanted him -- and I betcha there's a briefcase somewhere.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: What's in it?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Drugs?  Cash?  Both if we're lucky.

turns.speaker: UNCLE JOHN
turns.text: How we gonna get that lucky?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: While they're all fucking each other over ... couple of parties like us could move right in.

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: How'd you get in here.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Walked.

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: You walked.  What the hell are you doing here.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Looking for a bloke named Valentine. Know him?

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: He's expecting you?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I doubt it.

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: So why would he want to see you.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I have a message for him.  About Jennifer Wilson.

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: Jennifer Wilson.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: You know her?

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: Yeah.  I know her, all right.  She came down here once, stirred up a shitstorm. We lost a full day's work, took me weeks to get back on schedule.  If she hadn't a' been Terry's woman I would've broke her jaw.  'Course, she's nobody's problem now.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Is Valentine here?

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Where is he, then?

turns.speaker: SUPERVISOR
turns.text: Listen, get the fuck out of here before you get hurt.  Who the fuck do you think you are, waltzing in here, asking questions?

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Hello there.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Exercising my visitation rights.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Since when?

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: I miss my kids.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: They're at college.  Or doesn't your accountant even tell you where the money goes anymore.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: You've made it ... brighter.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I don't want you here, Terry.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Sure you do.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What kind of trouble are you in?

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: No trouble.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Surely you can think of somewhere else to take one of your chippies for a quick getaway.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Susan.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Where's ... what's-his-name -- Fred --

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: -- You know his name is Frank.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Is he here?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You know I don't live with him.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Go to him.  Go to his studio, or writers workshop or artists colony, Esselin retreat, nudist camp --

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Are you finished?

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: In a couple of days this whole thing --

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Who's looking for you?

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Go now.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It's been five minutes and I'm packing to leave again.  I can't believe this.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: That's right, your life is Shit, and I'm to blame.  It's that simple.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Pleasure.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Have we met?  There's something I can't quite --

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: EMI in London.  I work with Ian.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Ah.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: You must know Ian.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: I don't.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Great bloke.  Really turned things around there.  180 degrees.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: I suppose that's good, unless things were fine the way they were.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Oh, I think a shake-up was in order. Definitely.  Otherwise, people get lazy, don't they?  Forgetful.  Start thinking they can get away with things.  Gotta shake 'em up now and again, make 'em pay attention.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Thanks.  You, too.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Be seein' you.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: What.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: Tell you ...

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: About Jenny.  Tell me about Jenny.  About the <u>deal</u>.  Whatever fucking deal you had to kill my daughter for when she found out about it, you bastard.

turns.speaker: VALENTINE
turns.text: She could've had the deal!  I would've handed it to her if she wanted.  I would have given her everything.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: <u>Why</u> then.  Why did you do it!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Hello, Ed.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ann. Will you come in?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...I'm so sorry about your loss.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Yes. Thank you.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Of course, you know, Doris had nothing to do with it. Nothing at all.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, I know. Don't worry, Ed. I came to tell you...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yes, Ann?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: And you should tell Doris...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: We went camping last summer. In Eugene, Oregon. *Outside* of Eugene, Ed.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...Yes?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: At night, there were lights--we both saw them. We never told anyone, outside of our official report.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ann--

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: A spacecraft. I saw the creatures. They led Big Dave onto the craft. He never told anyone what they did, outside of his report. Of course he told *me*. No one else.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ann--

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: The government knows. I cannot repeat it to you. But this thing goes deep, Ed. This was not your wife. I goes deep, and involves the government. There is a great deal of fear. You know how certain circles would find it--the knowledge--a threat. They try to limit it, and--

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ann, will you come in, sit down, maybe have a drink?

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Sometimes knowledge is a curse, Ed. After this happened, things changed. Big Dave... he never touched me again.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...You don't like the music out there?

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: It's OK, I guess. No, I don't really. I'm not big on music, ordinarily.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hello, Rachel.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: I'm so sorry... I was sorry to hear.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah. Thanks.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: He was deaf when he wrote this.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Beethoven. He created it, and yet he never actually heard it. I suppose he heard it all in his head, somehow.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Hi, Mr Crane.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hello, Birdy. I thought that was very good.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Oh, in there? I messed up a little bit in the scherzo. I guess, if nobody noticed, it's OK. Mr Crane, this is Tony, a friend of mine. Tony, Mr Crane.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hello, Tony.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Hello, Mr Crane.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Hello, Birdy.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: We haven't seen you since... I'm terribly sorry.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: We've certainly missed you.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Birdy, I've been doing a lot of thinking. There are a lot of things that haven't worked out for me. Life has dealt me some bum cards...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...or maybe I just haven't played 'em right, I don't know. But you're--

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Pop doesn't like people smoking in here.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Sure... Sure, it's his house.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: That's what he keeps telling me.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Anyway, uh... my point is you're young. A kid really, your whole life ahead of you. But it's not too soon to start thinking... to start making opportunities for yourself. Before it all washes away.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Well, sure, I guess. Pop says so too. I work pretty hard at school.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: That's swell. However, the music, if you want to pursue it, well, the lessons from Mrs Swan, they'll only take you so far. There's this guy in San Francisco, I've made inquiries, everybody says he's the best. Trained lots of people who've gone on to have big concert careers, symphony orchestras, the works. His name is Jacques Carcanogues. I'm not sure I'm pronouncing it right. Anyway, he's a Frenchman.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Boy.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: You've got talent, anyone could see that. And he's the best. If he thinks a student has talent, he'll take 'em on for next to nothing. You're a cinch to be accepted, I could cover the cost of the lessons, like I said, it's pretty modest--

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Oh, Mr Crane--

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I have to do it. I can't stand by and watch more things go down the drain. You're young, you don't understand.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Geez, Mr Crane, I don't know. I hadn't really thought about a career or stuff.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I know you haven't. Look, just go meet him as a favor to me. I talked to this guy. Hope I pronounced his name right. He sounded very busy, but he's not a bad egg; he loosened up a little when I told him how talented you are. He agreed to see you this Saturday. He said maybe you were a diamond in the rough. His words.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Geez, Mr Crane.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Just see him, as a favor to me.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: ...I stank, didn't I?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: He didn't say that.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: But more or less.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Look, I'm no expert, but--

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: It doesn't matter, Mr Crane.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm sure there's a dozen teachers better than this clown. More qualified. Goddamn phony.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: But it doesn't matter. Really, I'm not interested in playing music professionally.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: ...I'm not certain I'll have a career at all, and if I do, I'll probably be a veterinarian.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: I do appreciate the interest you've taken, though.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Ah... it's nothing.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: I'm only sorry that I didn't play better for you. I know it would've made you happy. You know what you are?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: You're an enthusiast.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Huh. Yeah. Maybe...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...I guess I've been all wet.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: But I do appreciate it, Mr Crane...

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: ...I wanted to make you happy.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Birdy--

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: It's OK...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...No, please.

turns.speaker: BIRDY
turns.text: Please, Mr Crane, it's OK, please--

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: ...You are ze fahzer?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No. Uh... family friend.

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: I speak to you on ze phone, non? You have a special interest in music?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: Ah yes, a music lover.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Well, I don't pretend to be an expert.

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: Ah.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Well? How'd she do?

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: Ze girl?... She seems like a very nice girl. She *plays*, monsieur, like a very nice girl. Ztinks. Very nice girl. However, ztinks.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: Is not so hard to understand. Her playing, very polite.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Did she make mistakes?

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: Mistake, no, it says E-flat, she plays E-flat. Ping-ping. Hit the right note, always. Very proper.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I don't understand, no mistakes, she's just a kid--I thought you taught the, uh, the--

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: Ah, but that is just what I cannot teach. I cannot teach her to have a soul. Look, monsieur, play the piano, is not about the fingers. *Done* with the fingers, yes. But the music, she is inside. Inside, monsieur...

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: ...she can go up there.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Well, look, I don't claim to be an expert--

turns.speaker: CARCANOGUES
turns.text: Then you listen to me, for I am expert. That girl, she give me a headache. She cannot play. Nice girl. Very clever hands. Nice girl. Someday, I think, maybe, she make a very good typist.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: A goose, friend. I was chasing a wild goose. Ed, have you ever heard of venture capital?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Uh--

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Well, it's the wildest goose there is. Risk money. Very speculative. Except, Ed, in certain situations, it's not, see? I thought I had a prospect here. Well, I make the haul up and this lousy so-and-so tells me his situation has changed--all his capital's gonna be tied up in expansion plans of his own. Thank you, mother! Pop goes another bubble! It's only the biggest business opportunity since Henry Ford and I can't seem to interest a soul!

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: That right.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: It's called dry cleaning. You heard me right, brother, 'dry cleaning'-- wash without water, no suds, no tumble, no stress on the clothes. It's all done with chemicals, friend, and your garments end up crisp and fresh. And here's the capper: no shrinkage.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: That's right! Dry cleaning--remember the name. It's going to revolutionize the laundry industry, and those that get in early are gonna bear the fruit away. All I need is $10,000 to open my first store, then I use its cash flow to finance another, and so on-- leap frog, bootstrap myself a whole chain. Well, me and a partner. Cleanliness, friend. There's money in it. There's a future. There's room to grow... Say, that's looking pretty good. Let's see it with the hairpiece on...

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: ...Ed Crane. Remember? Today?

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Sorry, friend, I, uh, you got me at a disadvantage.

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: I'm, uh, I'm--the barber.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: Jesus! The barber! I'll be a sonofagun. Why didn't you say so? 'Course--the barber.

turns.speaker: CREIGHTON
turns.text: ...I didn't recognize you without the smock. Did I--damn--did I leave something at the shop?

turns.speaker: ED
turns.text: No. I might be interested in that, uh, business proposition--
